title: 115_hr5166
content: The Act titled "Protecting Consumer Information Act of 2018" establishes cybersecurity standards for certain consumer reporting agencies and service providers. The Commission will review and potentially revise cybersecurity standards for consumer reporting agencies and service providers under the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act to ensure protection against cyber attacks. The Commission will revise regulations to require consumer reporting agencies and service providers to maintain safeguards against cyber attacks within 180 days. An initial investigation will be conducted within 18 months. The Commission will investigate covered consumer reporting agencies and service providers to ensure compliance with regulations issued under the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act within a specified timeframe. The Commission will conduct investigations of covered consumer reporting agencies and service providers to verify compliance with regulations under the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act within a set timeframe, starting 18 months after the issuance of revised regulations. The Federal Trade Commission will enforce regulations under the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act. The Federal Trade Commission will enforce regulations under the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, treating violations by consumer reporting agencies or service providers as violations of unfair or deceptive acts or practices. The Commission will have the same enforcement powers and jurisdiction as under the Federal Trade Commission Act. Consumer reporting agencies or service providers that violate regulations under the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act will be subject to penalties and entitled to privileges under the Federal Trade Commission Act. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT BY STATE ATTORNEYS GENERAL. State attorneys general can bring civil actions on behalf of residents to enjoin acts or practices, enforce regulations, obtain damages, or seek other legal relief against consumer reporting agencies or service providers violating regulations under the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act. State attorneys general can bring civil actions on behalf of residents to enforce regulations against consumer reporting agencies or service providers under the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act. Before filing an action, the attorney general must provide written notice to the Commission and a copy of the complaint. The Commission has the authority to intervene in the action and be heard on all matters arising therein. State attorneys general can bring civil actions on behalf of residents to enforce regulations against consumer reporting agencies or service providers under the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act. If a federal action is pending, no State attorney general, official, or agency may bring an action under this section against any defendant named in the complaint in the Federal action for any violation of such regulation alleged in the complaint. Nothing in this Act shall prevent the filing of civil actions under this section. State attorneys general have the power to enforce regulations against consumer reporting agencies under the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act. They can conduct investigations, administer oaths, and compel witnesses to produce evidence as allowed by state laws. The Act defines key terms such as "Commission" as the Federal Trade Commission, "covered consumer reporting agency" as an agency that compiles consumer files nationwide, and "covered service provider" as an entity providing services to a consumer reporting agency.
